nodes.bodyText:
After your refactor, you have several wrapper methods left inside of PersistentMutationOutbox, which are ~one line long. I would remove these, and just call your dat astructure directly, instead of through these wrapper methods:

updateExitingQueueItemOrAppendNew
nextMutationForModelId
removeFromQueue
findPendingMutationById
@jamesonwilliams sure will revise
How about private final MutationQueue mutationQueue, as the data structure's name.
@jamesonwilliams good call. will revise

Should you implement any of the standard Java contracts? extends LinkedHashMap,  implements List, ... implements Comparable<T>, implements Collection<T>, etc.?

Also for name, I'd use MutationQueue. The PersistentMutationOutbox documentation should be updated to desribe how it differs from a MutationQueue -- that is, the outbox applies (what?) rules about populating the queue, etc.

This new class should have a corresponding MutationQueueTest.java which tests it as an isolated unit.
@jamesonwilliams will add some tests for this new class. I didnt implement collections' interface methods as they are not needed at MutationOutBox's use case, but i can add them
Instead of maintaining your own head and tail, can you use a linked list/map or some kind directly? "Mutation linked list has a (some type of) list, composed into it?"

@jamesonwilliams i was thinking about using LinkedListHashMap which internally does the same thing as my new data structure , but LinkedListHashMap doesnt expose the api to iterate the linkedlist from head to tail. Also same for LinkedList java standard implementation , if you try to remove it it will traverse through the entire LinkedList and find the target which is again O(N) time complexity.
This data structure is actually inspired by a leetcode question i did before:
https://leetcode.com/problems/lru-cache/
Its for LRU cache but does the same thing.
^ Please include standard copyright header (same for any new file in this PR.)

-            mutationOutbox.nextMutationForModelId(originalJoe.getId())
+            mutationOutbox.getMutationQueue().nextMutationForModelId(originalJoe.getId())

nodes.bodyText: @jamesonwilliams agree this is a better pattern, especially when it comes to dependency injection in testing, but it requires us to update the constructor which is a breaking change to all its consumers.  It also make all its consumer import the MutationQueue class hence couple with it, which those consumers may not even care about. Let me know what you think,

nodes.bodyText: I believe the checkstyle will want a separate import group between java.* and io.*. You can check by running ./gradlew check. Our build treats checkstyle issues as errors, not warnings.
@jamesonwilliams thanks, have revised all the checkstyle erros

minor: by convention, the rest of the code base separates declaration and assignment. So, these assignments would be moved to the constructor, to match the existing code style.
All of these variables can be marked as final.
The mutationMap can be just a private final Map<TimeBasedUuid, Node> mutationMap unless you need some special functionality of the HashMap when you interact with it, in particular.
@jamesonwilliams Make sense, will revise
Capital F, end with .. Fill out @param and @return -- same for all.
@jamesonwilliams revise already
You use public in a number of places in this PR. Do you need to? Can you reduce the access to package-private?
@jamesonwilliams will revise

Can be a final class, most likely.
The Queue<...> ends up bringing in a lot of methods, actually. Now that you've investigate that route, do you think they add value? Or not? It was an interesting idea, to implement the Queue interface, but perhaps it is overkill. Particularly if many will just throw an exception.

@jamesonwilliams  will revise according to your comments, you are actually right that using a Queue interface is a overkill, especially we cant even reference this object in MutationOutBox as a Queue because we need the findMutationById() method to be exposed which is not a standard Queue operation,
@jamesonwilliams made needed change in the latest commit :)
